abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fourth Highway
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project largely
            achieved its principal objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was substantial, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of the both Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, project design should be kept simple, with
            manageable components that can be handled through a single
            or few agencies. Second, project preparation needs to be
            improved to minimize costly variations during
            implementation. Third, pre-qualification procedures need to
            be improved in line with the Bank's current standard
            pre-qualification documents and rigorously implemented to
            avoid awarding contracts to firms lacking capacity. Fourth,
            highway sector investments should be carefully prioritized
            to ensure timely availability of counterpart funds. Fifth,
            alternative off-budget highway maintenance arrangements are
            needed to provide an adequate and reliable source of highway
            maintenance funding. Sixth, vehicle overloading must be
            effectively addressed to sustain highway network
            improvements. Finally, the use of local/in-country expertise
            should be maximized to reduce reliance on costly long-term
            expatriate input over extended periods.
